Levels.HAWOPI: Identify self as Hawaiian/Other Pacific Islander
Levels.INDALS: Identify self as American Indian/Alaska Native

ANYFAMPD.Description: Do you have any family history of Parkinson's Disease or Parkinsonism?

Levels.1: Yes
Idiopathic PD
Levels.2: Alzheimer's disease
Levels.3: Frontotemporal dementia
Levels.4: Corticobasal syndrome
Levels.17: No PD nor other neurological disorder

DXLVL.Description: Confidence in most likely primary diagnosis

Levels.1: Yes
Levels.2: Unknown

Levels.1: Yes
Levels.2: Unknown

Levels.1: Yes
Levels.2: Unknown

Levels.1: Yes
Levels.2: Unknown

Levels.1: Yes
Levels.2: Unknown

Levels.1: Original
Levels.2: Revised

Levels.1: Patient
Levels.2: Caregiver
Levels.3: Patient and Caregiver in Equal Proportion

Levels.1: Slight: Sleep problems are present but usually do not cause trouble getting a full night of sleep.
Levels.2: Mild: Sleep problems usually cause some difficulties getting a full night of sleep.
Levels.3: Moderate: Sleep problems cause a lot of difficulties getting a full night of sleep, but I still usually sleep for more than half the night.
Levels.4: Severe: I usually do not sleep for most of the night.

Levels.1: Slight: Daytime sleepiness occurs but I can resist and I stay awake.
Levels.2: Mild: Sometimes I fall asleep when alone and relaxing. For example, while reading or watching TV.
Levels.3: Moderate: I sometimes fall asleep when I should not. For example, while eating or talking with other people.
Levels.4: Severe: I often fall asleep when I should not. For example, while eating or talking with other people.

Levels.1: Slight: I have these feelings. However, I can do things and be with other people without difficulty.
Levels.2: Mild: These feelings cause some problems when I do things or am with other people.
Levels.3: Moderate: These feelings cause a lot of problems, but they do not stop me from doing things or being with other people.
Levels.4: Severe: These feelings stop me from doing things or being with other people.

Levels.1: Slight: I need to urinate often or urgently. However, these problems do not cause difficulties with my daily activities.
Levels.2: Mild: Urine problems cause some difficulties with my daily activities. However, I do not have urine accidents.
Levels.3: Moderate: Urine problems cause a lot of difficulties with my daily activities, including urine accidents.
Levels.4: Severe: I cannot control my urine and use a protective garment or have a bladder tube.

Levels.1: Slight: I have been constipated. I use extra effort to move my bowels. However, this problem does not disturb my activities or my being comfortable.
Levels.2: Mild: Constipation causes me to have some troubles doing things or being comfortable.
Levels.3: Moderate: Constipation causes me to have a lot of trouble doing things or being comfortable. However, it does not stop me from doing anything.
Levels.4: Severe: I usually need physical help from someone else to empty my bowels.

Levels.0: Normal: No dizzy or foggy feelings.
Levels.1: Slight: Dizzy or foggy feelings occur. However, they do not cause me troubles doing things.
Levels.2: Mild: Dizzy or foggy feeling cause me to hold on to something, but I do not need to sit or lie back down.
Levels.3: Moderate: Dizzy or foggy feelings cause me to sit or lie down to avoid fainting or falling.
Levels.4: Severe: Dizzy or foggy feelings cause me to fall or faint.

Levels.1: Slight: Fatigue occurs. However it does not cause me troubles doing things or being with people.
Levels.2: Mild: Fatigue causes me some troubles doing things or being with people.
Levels.3: Moderate: Fatigue causes me a lot of troubles doing things or being with people. However, it does not stop me from doing anything.
Levels.4: Severe: Fatigue stops me from doing things or being with people.

NP1PTOT.Description: MDS-UPDRS Part I (Patient Questionnaire) Total Score. Mapped using formula: NP1SLPN+NP1SLPD+NP1PAIN+NP1URIN+NP1CNST+NP1LTHD+NP1FAT

Levels.1: Slight: Impairment appreciated by patient or caregiver with no concrete interference with the patient's ability to carry out normal activities and social interactions.
Levels.2: Mild: Clinically evident cognitive dysfunction, but only minimal interference with the patient's ability to carry out normal activities and social interactions.
Levels.3: Moderate: Cognitive deficits interfere with but do not preclude the patient's ability to carry out normal activities and social interactions.
Levels.4: Severe: Cognitive dysfunction precludes the patient's ability to carry out normal activities and social interactions.

Levels.0: Normal: No hallucinations or psychotic behavior.
Levels.1: Slight: Illusions or non-formed hallucinations, but patient recognizes them without loss of insight.
Levels.2: Mild: Formed hallucinations independent of environmental stimuli. No loss of insight.
Levels.3: Moderate: Formed hallucinations with loss of insight.
Levels.4: Severe: Patient has delusions or paranoia.

Levels.1: Slight: Episodes of depressed mood that are not sustained for more than one day at a time. No interference with patient's ability to carry out normal activities and social interactions.
Levels.2: Mild: Depressed mood that is sustained over days, but without interference with normal activities and social interactions.
Levels.3: Moderate: Depressed mood that interferes with, but does not preclude the patient's ability to carry out normal activities and social interactions.
Levels.4: Severe: Depressed mood precludes patient's ability to carry out normal activities and social interactions.

Levels.1: Slight: Anxious feelings present but not sustained for more than one day at a time. No interference with patient's ability to carry out normal activities and social interactions.
Levels.2: Mild: Anxious feelings are sustained over more than one day at a time, but without interference with patient's ability to carry out normal activities and social interactions.
Levels.3: Moderate: Anxious feelings interfere with, but do not preclude, the patient's ability to carry out normal activities and social interactions.
Levels.4: Severe: Anxious feelings preclude patient's ability to carry out normal activities and social interactions.

Levels.1: Slight: Apathy appreciated by patient and/or caregiver, but no interference with daily activities and social interactions.
Levels.2: Mild: Apathy interferes with isolated activities and social interactions.
Levels.3: Moderate: Apathy interferes with most activities and social interactions.
Levels.4: Severe: Passive and withdrawn, complete loss of initiative.

Levels.1: Slight: Problems are present but usually do not cause any difficulties for the patient or family/caregiver.
Levels.2: Mild: Problems are present and usually cause a few difficulties in the patient's personal and family life.
Levels.3: Moderate: Problems are present and usually cause a lot of difficulties in the patient's personal and family life.
Levels.4: Severe: Problems are present and preclude the patient's ability to carry out normal activities or social interactions or to maintain previous standards in personal and family life.

NP1RTOT.Description: MDS-UPDRS Part I (Rater Completed) Total Score. Mapped using formula NP1COG+NP1HALL+NP1DPRS+NP1ANXS+NP1APAT+NP1DDS

Levels.1: Slight: My speech is soft, slurred or uneven, but it does not cause others to ask me to repeat myself.
Levels.2: Mild: My speech causes people to ask me to occasionally repeat myself, but not everyday.
Levels.3: Moderate: My speech is unclear enough that others ask me to repeat myself every day even though most of my speech is understood.
Levels.4: Severe: Most or all of my speech cannot be understood.

Levels.1: Slight: I have too much saliva, but do not drool.
Levels.2: Mild: I have some drooling during sleep, but none when I am awake.
Levels.3: Moderate: I have some drooling when I am awake, but I usually do not need tissues or a handkerchief.
Levels.4: Severe: I have so much drooling that I regularly need to use tissues or a handkerchief to protect my clothes.

Levels.1: Slight: I am aware of slowness in my chewing or increased effort at swallowing, but I do not choke or need to have my food specially prepared.
Levels.2: Mild: I need to have my pills cut or my food specially prepared because of chewing or swallowing problems, but I have not choked over the past week.
Levels.3: Moderate: I choked at least one in the past week.
Levels.4: Severe: Because of chewing and swallowing problems, I need a feed tube.

Levels.1: Slight: I am slow, but I do not need any help handling my food and have not had food spills while eating.
Levels.2: Mild: I am slow with my eating and have occasional food spills. I may need help with a few tasks such as cutting meat.
Levels.3: Moderate: I need help with many eating tasks but can manage some alone.
Levels.4: Severe: I need help for most or all eating tasks.

Levels.1: Slight: I am slow, but I do not need help.
Levels.2: Mild: I am slow and need help for a few dressing tasks (buttons, bracelets).
Levels.3: Moderate: I need help for many dressing tasks.
Levels.4: Severe: I need help for most or all dressing tasks.

Levels.1: Slight: I am slow, but I do not need help.
Levels.2: Mild: I need someone else to help me with some hygiene tasks.
Levels.3: Moderate: I need help for many hygiene tasks.
Levels.4: Severe: I need help for most or all hygiene tasks.

Levels.1: Slight: My writing is slow, clumsy or uneven, but all words are clear.
Levels.2: Mild: Some words are unclear and difficult to read.
Levels.3: Moderate: Many words are unclear and difficult to read.
Levels.4: Severe: Most or all words cannot be read.

Levels.1: Slight: I am a bit slow but do these activities easily.
Levels.2: Mild: I have some difficulty doing these activities.
Levels.3: Moderate: I have major problems doing these activities, but still do most.
Levels.4: Severe: I am unable to do most or all of these activities.

Levels.1: Slight: I have a bit of trouble turning, but I do not need any help.
Levels.2: Mild: I have a lot of trouble turning and need occasional help from someone else.
Levels.3: Moderate: To turn over I often need help from someone else.
Levels.4: Severe: I am unable to turn over without help from someone else.

Levels.0: Normal: Not at all. I have no shaking or tremor.
Levels.1: Slight: Shaking or tremor occurs but does not cause problems with any activities.
Levels.2: Mild: Shaking or tremor causes problems with only a few activities.
Levels.3: Moderate: Shaking or tremor causes problems with many of my daily activities.
Levels.4: Severe: Shaking or tremor causes problems with most or all activities.

NP2RISE.Description: GETTING OUT OF BED, CAR, OR DEEP CHAIR

Levels.1: Slight: I am slow or awkward, but I usually can do it on my first try.
Levels.2: Mild: I need more than one try to get up or need occasional help.
Levels.3: Moderate: I sometimes need help to get up, but most times I can still do it on my own.
Levels.4: Severe: I need help most or all of the time.

Levels.1: Slight: I briefly freeze but I can easily start walking again. I do not need help from someone else or a walking aid (cane or walker) because of freezing.
Levels.2: Mild: I freeze and have trouble starting to walk again, but I do not need someone's help or a walking aid (cane or walker) because of freezing.
Levels.3: Moderate: When I freeze I have a lot of trouble starting to walk again and, because of freezing, I sometimes need to use a walking aid or need someone else's help.
Levels.4: Severe: Because of freezing, most or all of the time, I need to use a walking aid or someone's help.

NP2PTOT.Description: MDS-UPDRS Part II Total Score. Mapped using formula NP2SPCH+NP2SALV+NP2SWAL+NP2EAT+NP2DRES+NP2HYGN+NP2HWRT+NP2HOBB+NP2TURN+NP2TRMR+NP2RISE+NP2WALK+NP2FREZ

PDTRTMNT.Description: Is the participant on medication or receiving deep brain stimulation for treating the symptoms of Parkinsons disease?

Levels.1: Yes

PDSTATE.Description: Which functional state is the participant currently in?

Levels.OFF: Off is the typical functional state when participants have a poor response in spite of taking medications
Levels.ON: On is the typical functional state when patients are receiving medication and have a good response

HRPOSTMED.Description: Hours between last dose of PD medication and NUPDRS3 exam

PDMEDYN.Description: Is participant on medication for PD?

Levels.1: Yes
Yes
Slight: Loss of modulation, diction or volume, but still all words easy to understand.
Levels.2: Mild: Loss of modulation, diction, or volume, with a few words unclear, but the overall sentences easy to follow.
Levels.3: Moderate: Speech is difficult to understand to the point that some, but not most, sentences are poorly understood.
Levels.4: Severe: Most speech is difficult to understand or unintelligible.

Levels.1: Slight: Minimal masked facies manifested only by decreased frequency of blinking.
Levels.2: Mild: In addition to decreased eye-blink frequency, Masked facies present in the lower face as well, namely fewer movements around the mouth, such as less spontaneous smiling, but lips not parted.
Levels.3: Moderate: Masked facies with lips parted some of the time when the mouth is at rest.
Levels.4: Severe: Masked facies with lips parted most of the time when the mouth is at rest.

Levels.1: Slight: Rigidity only detected with activation maneuver.
Levels.2: Mild: Rigidity detected without the activation maneuver, but full range of motion is easily achieved.
Levels.3: Moderate: Rigidity detected without the activation maneuver, full range of motion is achieved with effort.
Levels.4: Severe: Rigidity detected without the activation maneuver and full range of motion not achieved.

Levels.1: Slight: Any of the following: a) the regular rhythm is broken with one or two interruptions or hesitations of the tapping movement; b) slight slowing; c) the amplitude decrements near the end of the 10 taps.
Levels.2: Mild: Any of the following: a) 3 to 5 interruptions during tapping; b) mild slowing; c) the amplitude decrements midway in the 10-tap sequence.
Levels.3: Moderate: Any of the following: a) more than 5 interruptions during tapping or at least one longer arrest (freeze) in ongoing movement; b) moderate slowing; c) the amplitude decrements starting after the first tap.
Levels.4: Severe: Cannot or can only barely perform the task because of slowing, interruptions or decrements.

Levels.0: Normal: No problems. Able to arise quickly without hesitation.
Levels.1: Slight: Arising is slower than normal; or may need more than one attempt; or may need to move forward in the chair to arise. No need to use the arms of the chair.
Levels.2: Mild: Pushes self up from arms of chair without difficulty.
Levels.3: Moderate: Needs to push off, but tends to fall back; or may have to try more than one time using arms of chair, but can get up without help.
Levels.4: Severe: Unable to arise without help.

Levels.0: Normal: No problems. Able to arise quickly without hesitation.
Levels.1: Slight: Independent walking with minor gait impairment.
Levels.2: Mild: Independent walking but with substantial gait impairment.
Levels.3: Moderate: Requires an assistance device for safe walking (walking stick, walker) but not a person.
Levels.4: Severe: Cannot walk at all or only with another person's assistance.

Levels.1: Slight: Freezes on starting, turning or walking through doorway with a single halt during any of these events, but then continues smoothly without freezing during straight walking.
Levels.2: Mild: Freezes on starting, turning or walking through doorway with more than one halt during any of these activities, but continues smoothly without freezing during straight walking.
Levels.3: Moderate: Freezes once during straight walking.
Levels.4: Severe: Freezes multiple times during straight walking.

Levels.0: Normal: No problems: Recovers with one or two steps.
Levels.1: Slight: 3-5 steps, but subject recovers unaided.
Levels.2: Mild: More than 5 steps, but subject recovers unaided.
Levels.3: Moderate: Stands safely, but with absence of postural response; falls if not caught by examiner.
Levels.4: Severe: Very unstable, tends to lose balance spontaneously or with just a gentle pull on the shoulders.

Levels.1: Slight: Not quite erect, but posture could be normal for older person.
Levels.2: Mild: Definite flexion, scoliosis or leaning to one side, but patient can correct posture to normal posture when asked to do so.
Levels.3: Moderate: Stooped posture, scoliosis or leaning to one side that cannot be corrected volitionally to a normal posture by the patient.
Levels.4: Severe: Flexion, scoliosis or leaning with extreme abnormality of posture.

Levels.1: Slight: Slight global slowness and poverty of spontaneous movements.
Levels.2: Mild: Mild global slowness and poverty of spontaneous movements.
Levels.3: Moderate: Moderate global slowness and poverty of spontaneous movements.
Levels.4: Severe: Severe global slowness and poverty of spontaneous movements.

Levels.1: Slight: Tremor is present but less than 1 cm in amplitude.
Levels.2: Mild: Tremor is at least 1, but less than 3 cm in amplitude.
Levels.3: Moderate: Tremor is at least 3, but less than 10 cm in amplitude.
Levels.4: Severe: Tremor is at least 10 cm in amplitude.

Levels.1: Slight: < 1 cm in maximal amplitude.
Levels.2: Mild: >= 1 cm but < 3 cm in maximal amplitude.
Levels.3: Moderate: >= 3 cm but < 10 cm in maximal amplitude.
Levels.4: Severe: >= 10 cm in maximal amplitude.

Levels.1: Slight: Tremor at rest is present < 25% of the entire examination period.
Levels.2: Mild: Tremor at rest is present 26-50% of the entire examination period.
Levels.3: Moderate: Tremor at rest is present 51-75% of the entire examination period.
Levels.4: Severe: Tremor at rest is present > 75% of the entire examination period.

NP3TOT.Description: MDS-UPDRS Part III Total Score. Mapped using formula NP3SPCH+NP3FACXP+NP3RIGN+NP3RIGRU+NP3RIGLU+PN3RIGRL+NP3RIGLL+NP3FTAPR+NP3FTAPL+NP3HMOVR+NP3HMOVL+NP3PRSPR+NP3PRSPL+NP3TTAPR+NP3TTAPL+NP3LGAGR+NP3LGAGL+NP3RISNG+NP3GAIT+NP3FRZGT+NP3PSTBL+NP3POSTR+NP3BRADY+NP3PTRMR+NP3PTRML+NP3KTRMR+NP3KTRML+NP3RTARU+NP3RTALU+NP3RTARL+NP3RTALL+NP3RTALJ+NP3RTCON

Levels.1: Yes
Yes
Unilateral movement only.
Levels.2: Bilateral involvement without impairment of balance.
Levels.3: Mild to moderate involvement; some postural instability but physically independent; needs assistance to recover from pull test.
Levels.4: Severe disability; still able to walk or stand unassisted.

Levels.1: Slight: <= 25% of waking day.
Levels.2: Mild: 26 - 50% of waking day.
Levels.3: Moderate: 51 - 75% of waking day.
Levels.4: Severe: > 75% of waking day.

Levels.0: Normal: No dyskinesias or no impact by dyskinesias on activities or social interactions.
Levels.1: Slight: Dyskinesias impact on a few activities, but the patient usually performs all activities and participates in all social interactions during dyskinetic periods.
Levels.2: Mild: Dyskinesias impact on many activities, but the patient usually performs all activities and participates in all social interactions during dyskinetic periods.
Levels.3: Moderate: Dyskinesias impact on activities to the point that the patient usually does not perform some activities or does not usually participate in some social activities during dyskinetic episodes.
Levels.4: Severe: Dyskinesias impact on function to the point that the patient usually does not perform most activities or participate in most social interactions during dyskinetic episodes.

NP4OFF.Description: 4.3 Time spent in the OFF state

Levels.1: Slight: <= 25% of waking day.
Levels.2: Mild: 26 - 50% of waking day.
Levels.3: Moderate: 51 - 75% of waking day.
Levels.4: Severe: > 75% of waking day.

Levels.0: Normal: No fluctuations or no impact by fluctuations on performance of activities or social interactions.
Levels.1: Slight: Fluctuations impact on a few activities, but during OFF, the patient usually performs all activities and participates in all social interactions that typically occur during the ON state.
Levels.2: Mild: Fluctuations impact many activities, but during OFF, the patient still usually performs all activities and participates in all social interactions that typically occur during the ON state.
Levels.3: Moderate: Fluctuations impact on the performance of activities during OFF to the point that the patient usually does not perform some activities or participate in some social interactions that are performed during ON periods.
Levels.4: Severe: Fluctuations impact on function to the point that, during OFF, the patient usually does not perform most activities or participate in most social interactions that are performed during ON periods.

Levels.1: Slight: OFF times are predictable all or almost all of the time (> 75%)
Levels.2: Mild: OFF times are predictable most of the time (51-75%).
Levels.3: Moderate: OFF times are predictable some of the time (26-50%).
Levels.4: Severe: OFF episodes are rarely predictable (<= 25%).

Levels.0: Normal: No dystonia OR NO OFF TIME.
Levels.1: Slight: <= 25% of time in OFF state.
Levels.2: Mild: 26 - 50% of time in OFF state.
Levels.3: Moderate: 51 - 75% of time in OFF state.
Levels.4: Severe: > 75% of time in OFF state.

NP4TOT.Description: MDS-UPDRS Part IV Total Score. Mapped using formula NP4WDYSK+NP4DYSKI+NP4OFF+NP4FLCTI+NP4FLCTX+NP4DYSTN

DATSCAN_CAUDATE_R.Description: Striatal Binding Ratio of the Right Caudate Small brain region of interest referenced to the Occipital Lobe

DATSCAN_CAUDATE_L.Description: Striatal Binding Ratio of the Left Caudate Small brain region of interest referenced to the Occipital Lobe

DATSCAN_PUTAMEN_R.Description: Striatal Binding Ratio of the Right Putamen Small brain region of interest referenced to the Occipital Lobe

DATSCAN_PUTAMEN_L.Description: Striatal Binding Ratio of the Left Putamen Small brain region of interest referenced to the Occipital Lobe

DATSCAN_PUTAMEN_R_ANT.Description: Striatal Binding Ratio of the Right Anterior Putamen brain region of interest, referenced to the Occipital Lobe

DATSCAN_PUTAMEN_L_ANT.Description: Striatal Binding Ratio of the Left Anterior Putamen brain region of interest, referenced to the Occipital Lobe

DATSCAN.Description: DAT imaging and SPECT scan completed

Levels.1: Completed at this visit
Levels.2: Completed using a previously acquired dopamine imaging scan (i.e., acquired prior to participant's consent to PPMI)

PREVDATDT.Description: Date of DaTscan imaging completed previously

Levels.1: Consistent with evidence
Levels.2: Not consistent with evidence
Levels.3: No visual interpretation report provided

DATSCAN_TOTAL_DOSE_MBq.Description: Decay Corrected Total Dose in MBq

DATSCAN_QUALITY_RATING.Description: Overall Image Quality Rating determined by Image Quality Control

Levels.1: 1= Good quality
Levels.2: 2= Adequate quality
Levels.3: 3= Lower quality

DATSCAN_VISINTRP.Description: Overall Majority Read Visual Interpretation Result

MRI_SCAN_QUALITY_RATING.Description: Overall Image Quality Rating determined by Image Quality Control

MRI_SCAN_ANALYZED.Description: Is the MRI scan able to be analyzed?

Levels.1: Normal
Levels.2: Abnormal, not clinically significant
Levels.3: Abnormal, clinically significant

AV133_RCAUD_S.Description: Striatal Binding Ratio of the Right Caudate Small brain region of interest referenced to the Occipital Lobe

AV133_RPUTANT_S.Description: Striatal Binding Ratio of the Right Putament Anterior referenced to the Occipital Lobe

AV133_RPUTPOST_S.Description: Striatal Binding Ratio of the Right Putamen Posterior referenced to the Occipital Lobe

AV133_LCAUD_S.Description: Striatal Binding Ratio of the Left Caudate Small brain region of interest referenced to the Occipital Lobe

AV133_LPUTANT_S.Description: Striatal Binding Ratio of the Left Putamen Anterior referenced to the Occipital Lobe

AV133_LPUTPOST_S.Description: Striatal Binding Ratio of the Left Putamen Posterior referenced to the Occipital Lobe

AV133_TOTAL_DOSE_CALC.Description: Decay Corrected Total Dose Calculation in MBQ

AV133_SCAN_QUALITY_RATING.Description: Overall Image Quality Rating determined by Image Quality Control

Levels.1: 1= Good quality
Levels.2: 2= Adequate quality
Levels.3: 3= Lower quality

LDOPA.Description: Levodopa at each point in time.

LEDD.Description: Levodopa Equivalent Daily Dose at each point in time. (considers all Parkinsonian medications)

MCATOT.Description: MoCA total score. Il punteggio massimo totale Ã¨ di 30 punti. I pazienti con punteggi inferiori a 26 potrebbero essere a rischio di disfunzioni cognitive
